So including but not limited to to SARS like viruses. Um, we just try to compare different kinds of of model structures and one of the things that we found when kind of validating everything was definitely that if you take um you know, models that incorporate any kind of trait information on in this case that ecology, but you know, any kind of host ecology, those seem to to definitely outperform other approaches using, you know, kind of network structure of the the host pathogen network or something like that. So it's not I guess that's not really as much about um, you know, contact or fine scale ecology per se, but you know, even just thinking about this really big macro scale prediction, you know, we we do kind of expect the the ecology of the reservoir host to play a really important role and even describing very broad scale um predictive patterns. I'm sure as we we dig down more into actual, you know, contact and all of that with humans that that only kind of improves it more, but um yeah, I guess just seconding Kim on on just the importance of kind of even just basic ecological information about about different species almost sort of like natural history work is really foundational. We we lack that for a lot of lot of mammals and and birds still.
